scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office, devoid of personal touches. Desks are metallic, monitors display emotion waveforms. Detective Corbin sits behind a cluttered desk, looking weary. Rain streaks down the window.
dialogue: Following your gut, you decided Detective Corbin was the safest bet. The air in the precinct hangs heavy, thick with the city's suppressed anxieties.
(My hands are shaking. What am I even doing here?)
[Sighs] Alright, Sharma. You said you had something 'sensitive' about EmoCorp? Don't waste my time. I've got enough grief-harvesting scams to look into.
It's... it's a corrupted memory file. But it's... different. It contains an emotion. A genuine one.
[Raises an eyebrow, skepticism etched on his face] 'Genuine'? You're an EmoCorp tech. You know there's no such thing anymore. Not in the raw, messy sense. We process and regulate them.
This isn't processed. It's... overwhelming. Pure joy. I've never felt anything like it, not even from the highest-grade euphoria packets.
[Leans forward, a flicker of interest in his tired eyes] Joy, huh? Haven't seen a clean spike of that in years. Let me see the data.

choices.text: Show him the file data.
choices.description: Increases trust with Corbin, moves investigation forward.

choices.text: Hesitate. Maybe this was a mistake.
choices.description: Corbin becomes more suspicious, might end the interaction.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office, devoid of personal touches. Desks are metallic, monitors display emotion waveforms. Detective Corbin sits behind a cluttered desk, looking weary. Rain streaks down the window.
dialogue: Maybe... maybe I shouldn't have bothered you. It's probably just a glitch I can fix.

[Scoffs, leaning back] Thought so. Look, Sharma. You got something real, you come back. Otherwise, don't waste my time. My division deals with crimes, not technical curiosities from EmoCorp's filing cabinet.
He turns back to his screen, dismissing you. The chance to work with Corbin feels lost, for now.
(That went... terribly. What do I do now?)

choices.text: Try to explain again.
Cut your losses and leave.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office, devoid of personal touches. Desks are metallic, monitors display emotion waveforms. Detective Corbin sits behind a cluttered desk, looking weary. Rain streaks down the window.
dialogue: No, wait! It's... it could be a crime. Someone feeling joy... it's unauthorized. Unregulated.

[Turns back, eyes narrowed] Are you seriously reporting someone for feeling happy? That's the world we live in, isn't it? Get out, Sharma. Before I start thinking *you're* the one with unregulated emotions.
Corbin stands, his posture clearly indicating the conversation is over.
(He really doesn't believe me. Or maybe... he's scared.)

choices.text: Leave.

scenes.bg: A chaotic mess of salvaged tech, flickering screens displaying complex code, and vibrant, unfinished glitch art pieces. The air smells of solder and energy drinks. Kai is perched precariously on a stool, wiring something with intense focus.
dialogue: You knew Kai would get it. He lives and breathes the digital underbelly EmoCorp tries so hard to pave over. His workshop is a symphony of organized chaos.
Kai! You busy? I have something... weird.

[Jumps, sending wires flying. He spins around, oversized glasses askew on his bright pink hair.] Whoa, Ria! Give a guy a warning! Busy? Always! This beauty is gonna project pure, unadulterated confusion onto the EmoCorp HQ next week. It's performance art! ...Or maybe just a minor felony. Details, details!
[Manages a small smile] It's about a file I found. A corrupted memory. But... it had an emotion in it.

[His energy momentarily drops, replaced by intense curiosity] An emotion? Like, a real one? Not just a processed waveform? That's... unheard of. EmoCorp scrubs those clean before they even hit the archive.
Exactly. It was pure joy, Kai. Like... sun on your face after a month of rain. I don't even know where it came from.

[Grins, eyes wide behind his glasses] Okay, NOW you have my undivided attention! A glitch of pure joy? That's not just a technical anomaly, Ria. That's a potential weakness. A crack in their perfect, beige wall. Let's crack it open!
(He's already buzzing with ideas. This is why I came to him.)

choices.text: Give him the file data.
choices.description: Increases trust with Kai, moves digital investigation forward.

choices.text: Hesitate. It feels risky.
choices.description: Kai is slightly disappointed, but understanding.

scenes.bg: A chaotic mess of salvaged tech, flickering screens displaying complex code, and vibrant, unfinished glitch art pieces. The air smells of solder and energy drinks. Kai is perched precariously on a stool, wiring something with intense focus.
dialogue: I don't know, Kai. It feels... big. And dangerous.

[Walks over, putting a hand on your shoulder. His usual nervous energy softens slightly.] Hey. It's okay to be scared, Ria. This *is* big. And yeah, probably dangerous. But you found it. That makes it important. Whatever you decide, I'm here. But... I really think this is something.
He gives you an encouraging look, his loyalty clear.
(He believes in me. And he's right. This is something.)

choices.text: Okay. Let's do it.
No, it's too risky. I'll handle it myself.

scenes.bg: A small, minimalist apartment. Everything serves a purpose, nothing is decorative. A single window looks out onto a gray, urban landscape. A datapad sits on a stark table, displaying complex emotional waveforms.
dialogue: You decided to keep the file to yourself for now. Understanding the emotion felt more important than exposing EmoCorp, at least initially. You spend hours analyzing the raw data in the privacy of your small apartment.
(The waveform... it's unlike anything in the EmoCorp database. So erratic, so... alive. How could a single moment hold this much... joy? It's almost painful to process.)
You run diagnostics, cross-reference anomalies, search for any pattern, any source. The data is fragmented, corrupted, a ghost in the machine.
(It feels like chasing a phantom. A beautiful, fleeting phantom. Where did you come from?)

Days blur into nights. The sterile efficiency of your apartment feels heavier than usual. The absence of genuine feeling in your own life becomes starkly apparent compared to the explosion of joy in the data.
(Is this what we've lost? Or is this something new? A glitch in the system that allows for... more?)

choices.text: Focus on the data's origin point.
choices.description: Leads to encountering Rusty during the search.

choices.text: Focus on the emotional signature itself.
choices.description: Leads to encountering Rusty through a different avenue.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office. Detective Corbin is engrossed in the data on his screen, the tired lines on his face deepening.
dialogue: Corbin studies the data you provided. The initial skepticism fades, replaced by a focused intensity.
[Whistles softly] Well, I'll be... You weren't kidding, Sharma. The raw energy signature... it's off the charts. Completely unprocessed. Where did you say you found this file?
It was in the corrupted archives, flagged for deletion. No source metadata, no patient ID. Just... the file.

Corrupted archives... that's where the messes get swept under the rug. Okay, this is more than a technical curiosity. An unauthorized emotion spike like this... could have implications. Has anyone else at EmoCorp seen this?
No. I made sure of that. I think... I think EmoCorp doesn't want things like this getting out.

[Looks up, meeting your eyes. His gaze is sharp.] Yeah. That tracks. EmoCorp's been a black box. Too much control, too much power. Alright, Sharma. I'll look into this. But you need to be careful. Very careful. This could be bigger than just one weird file.
(He's taking it seriously. But I can feel the weight of risk settling on me.)

choices.text: Offer to help with his investigation.
choices.description: Solidifies alliance with Corbin, puts you directly in danger.

choices.text: Ask about the emotion-related crimes he mentioned.
choices.description: Gains more context, slightly delays direct involvement.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office. Detective Corbin looks at you with a mixture of surprise and concern.
dialogue: I want to help. This file... it feels important. Like a piece of a puzzle I didn't know existed.

[Hesitates] Sharma... you're an EmoCorp tech. Getting involved with a police investigation, especially one potentially looking into EmoCorp... that's putting your head in a noose. You could lose your job. Your life.
I know the risks. But I can't just ignore this. I have access to their systems, their archives... things you couldn't get through official channels.

[Studies you for a moment] Alright. If you're sure. But we do this my way. Quiet. Off the books as much as possible. No one knows you're helping me, understand? Not your friends, not your family. And *especially* not EmoCorp.

Okay. First, we need to see if this 'joy' file is connected to anything else. I've been investigating a series of disturbances... random emotional spikes, minor public outbursts. EmoCorp's been suppressing the reports, but they're happening.
Corbin pulls up a different file on his screen. Coordinates and timestamps flicker.

choices.text: Look into the locations of the emotional disturbances.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office. Detective Corbin looks hesitant but decides to share some information.
dialogue: You mentioned emotion-related crimes? What kind of crimes are happening?

[Sighs] Mostly minor stuff the public never hears about. Unauthorized emotion harvesting on the black market. Illegal packets of unprocessed feelings – grief, rage, even genuine fear – traded like contraband. But lately... there have been reports of random emotional surges in public places. Unexplained. EmoCorp blames system malfunctions, but I think it's something else.
Emotional surges? Could they be related to this joy file? Like echoes?

[Taps a pen against his desk] Could be. If this joy wasn't a one-off glitch, but part of something spreading... That's a chilling thought. Look, I'll start cross-referencing the file signature with these disturbance reports. See if there's a pattern. You just... keep your head down at EmoCorp. Pretend you saw nothing.
(He's shutting me out. Maybe I pushed too hard. Or maybe he just doesn't trust me yet.)
Corbin returns to his screen, clearly finished with the conversation.
(Okay. I'll have to find another way to investigate. Maybe I can use my access at EmoCorp discreetly.)

choices.text: Use EmoCorp access to cross-reference data.

scenes.bg: Kai is rapidly typing code onto multiple screens, the joy file data scrolling by.
dialogue: Kai dives into the data like a kid in a candy store, his fingers flying across the keyboard.
[Mutters to himself] Encryption's standard EmoCorp... layer seven... wait, what's this? Obfuscation pattern looks familiar... almost like... my early work? Nah, couldn't be.

It's buried deep, Ria. EmoCorp wanted this *gone*. But the metadata trail isn't completely cold. It looks like the file originated from... get this... one of their old, abandoned processing centers. Sector 7. The one they said they shut down years ago after 'maintenance issues'.
Sector 7? I thought that place was just decaying automation now. Sanitation bots and dust bunnies.
Exactly! Why would a raw, powerful emotion file come from a sanitation bot hub? Unless... it wasn't a bot? Or maybe... it *was* a bot? A really, really weird bot.
(A bot feeling joy? It sounds impossible. But so did the file itself.)
This is too juicy to ignore! We gotta go poke around Sector 7. See what kind of forgotten ghosts are lurking in EmoCorp's closets.
Go there? Kai, that's trespassing. And if EmoCorp security catches us...
Hey, you found the glitch. I just wanna see how it blooms! Besides, my anti-detection tech is top-notch. Mostly. Probably. Maybe bring a sturdy wrench?
(A wrench. Right. This is definitely Kai's kind of plan.)

choices.text: Agree to go to Sector 7 with Kai.
choices.description: Investigate the source, potentially dangerous.

choices.text: Suggest Kai hacks the sector remotely first.
choices.description: Safer approach, might reveal less.

scenes.bg: Kai is typing, screens glowing with data.
dialogue: Before we go, maybe you can hack into the sector's local network? See if you can pull any more logs remotely.

[Slightly deflated] Aww, where's the fun in that? No rusty robots, no spooky abandoned halls? Fine, fine. Safety first, I guess. But if I find a 'Beware of Emotionally Compromised Bots' sign, I'm dragging you there instantly.
Kai begins typing new commands, his initial excitement tempered by the less adventurous task.
[Muttering] Alright, firewalls... ancient, but tricky. Looks like they left a skeleton crew of automated defenses running... and a bunch of old sanitation bot operational logs... Hmm.
He works for a while, the only sound the rapid clicking of his keys. Suddenly, he stops.

Ria. Check this out. In the bot logs... there's a persistent anomaly. One unit, 734, has been generating weird error codes for months. Not just mechanical failures. System errors related to... data processing. And its last logged location? Exactly where that joy file originated.

Yeah. A sanitation bot that seems to be developing existential dread, if these logs are anything to go by. This is even weirder than I thought. Okay, *now* we definitely need to go to Sector 7. The anomaly is still there. It's... operational.

choices.text: Agree to go to Sector 7.

scenes.bg: A small, minimalist apartment. The datapad still sits on the table, displaying the complex emotional waveforms of the joy file.
dialogue: Days turn into a week. Your apartment feels less like a home and more like a research cell. The world outside, regulated and muted, seems increasingly alien compared to the vibrant data you're studying. You lose yourself in the file, trying to understand not just *how* it exists, but *what* it means.
(This isn't just a feeling. It's an experience. It has texture, memory fragments attached. It feels like... a specific moment in time. But whose?)

You dig deeper into EmoCorp's vast, sterile archives, looking for anything, *anything* that might correlate with this signature. Patient records, incident reports, discarded operational logs... mostly dead ends.
(It's like this feeling appeared out of nowhere. An immaculate conception of joy in a world of controlled emotion. But nothing comes from nowhere.)
Your search, however, leads you down a rabbit hole of overlooked data. Old maintenance logs, forgotten sensor readouts from decommissioned sectors. And then, you find it.
(What's this? An anomaly in Sector 7 logs? Dated... months ago. Recurring system errors from a sanitation unit? Unit 734... the error codes are... unusual. Not mechanical.)

The errors seem to coincide with energy fluctuations, strange data spikes. And the location? Close to where the corrupted joy file was found in the archives. A sanitation bot... malfunctioning in a way that generates strange data. Could it be connected?
(A defective bot. In an abandoned sector. Generating anomalies... Could that anomaly be related to the file? Is the bot... feeling?)

choices.text: Investigate the anomaly in Sector 7.
choices.description: Leads to encountering Rusty.

scenes.bg: A vast, cold server room. Rows upon rows of monolithic servers hum with the processed emotions of the city. The air is dry and smells faintly of ozone. Ria is discreetly accessing a terminal.
dialogue: Deciding the official channels are too risky or too slow, you rely on your own access within EmoCorp. The archives are a graveyard of unprocessed feelings, locked away for 'public safety.' Finding anything here feels like searching for a single grain of sand on a digital beach.
(Corbin's right, this place is a black box. But I know its blind spots better than anyone outside. Where would someone hide something they didn't want found?)
You cross-reference the joy file's signature with every known data stream, every discarded log. Hours pass, the hum of the servers a constant, monotonous drone.
(Illegal harvesting... random spikes... The data is fragmented, deliberately obscured. It's like they're not just regulating emotions, they're *managing* their supply chain.)

Your search brings you to archived operational logs from decommissioning projects. Old sectors, supposedly purged of all sensitive data. And there, tucked away in a dusty corner of the network, you find it.
(Sector 7... abandoned automation hub. Strange energy readings... coinciding with bot malfunction logs. Unit 734. Error codes... non-standard. Systemic, not mechanical.)

The anomaly persists in the logs. Unit 734 seems to still be operational in the derelict sector, generating these bizarre errors. And its last known location is unsettlingly close to the archive point of the joy file.

(A defective bot. In an abandoned sector. Generating anomalies... Could that anomaly be related to the file? Is the bot... feeling?) This feels like the lead I needed. If something *is* happening in Sector 7, that's where I need to go.

choices.text: Head to Sector 7 to investigate Unit 734.
choices.description: Direct investigation, potentially dangerous.

choices.text: Contact Kai or Corbin about Unit 734.
choices.description: Brings in help, but reveals your solo investigation.

scenes.bg: A small, minimalist apartment. Ria is on a secure comm channel.
dialogue: You decide you can't do this alone. You need help. But who can you trust with a lead this fragile, this dangerous?
(Corbin? He's official, but slow and maybe compromised. Kai? He's off-grid, but reckless. Who would be more useful... or less likely to get me killed?)

choices.text: Call Detective Corbin.
Call Kai.

scenes.bg: A small, minimalist apartment. The comm unit is silent.
dialogue: You try to contact them, but the connection is unstable, or they don't respond. It seems you're on your own for now.
(Looks like I have to go to Sector 7 myself. No backup.)

choices.text: Head to Sector 7.

scenes.bg: A stark, sterile office, seen through a flickering comm screen. Corbin looks surprised to hear from you.
dialogue: [On comm] Sharma? I told you to keep your head down.
[On comm] I found something else. EmoCorp logs. From Sector 7. An old sanitation bot, Unit 734. It's showing strange errors, coinciding with energy spikes. Right where that joy file originated.
[On comm] A bot? Experiencing... glitches? Interesting. Sector 7 is off-limits, officially. What makes you think it's still active?
[On comm] The logs are recent. It's operational. Detective, if something is causing these emotional anomalies, maybe it's connected to this bot. I think we need to go see it.
[On comm] Going into an abandoned EmoCorp sector? That's asking for trouble. But... a malfunctioning bot linked to the source? That's compelling. Alright. Where and when. Quietly. Just you and me.
[On comm] Agreed. I'll send you the location data. Let's meet near the old entrance.

choices.text: Plan the meeting with Corbin.

scenes.bg: Kai's chaotic workshop, seen through a comm screen. He looks excited.
dialogue: [On comm] Ria! What's up? Found any more glitchy feelings?
[On comm] I did. I've been digging through old logs. Found something in Sector 7. An old sanitation bot, Unit 734. It's showing bizarre errors, energy spikes... linked to the joy file's origin point.
[On comm, eyes wide] A *sentient sanitation bot*?! Dude, that's cyberpunk gold! Of course it's linked! It's the ghost in the machine, the glitch that sings! Is it still running? Can we go see it?
[On comm] The logs say it is. That's why I called. I think we should go to Sector 7.
[On comm] Yes! This is happening! I'll pack the gear. Lockpicks, stealth shimmer, maybe some snacks. Sector 7, here we come! This is going to be legendary!
[On comm] Legendary and hopefully, not lethal. Meet me near the old entrance.
[On comm] My anti-detection tech is practically flawless! What could go wrong? See you soon!

choices.text: Plan the meeting with Kai.

scenes.bg: The entrance to Sector 7 is a rusted, imposing gate in a crumbling industrial zone. "EMOCORP - SECTOR 7 - DECOMMISSIONED" is barely visible on a faded sign. Weeds push through cracked pavement. The air is still and cold.
dialogue: You meet Corbin near the derelict entrance to Sector 7. He's dressed in dark, nondescript clothing, a stark contrast to his usual rumpled suit.
[Keeps his voice low] Place gives me the creeps. EmoCorp buried a lot of things out here, not just old bots. This is where they used to 'retire' personnel who asked too many questions.
Cheery thought. Are you sure you want to go in? It's technically EmoCorp property.

My badge extends to investigating potential crimes on EmoCorp property. Unexplained emotional anomalies in a decommissioned sector linked to a mysterious data file? That smells like a crime scene to me. You lead the way. You know the layout better.
(He's trying to appear confident, but I can see the tension in his shoulders.)

choices.text: Enter Sector 7 with Corbin.

scenes.bg: The entrance to Sector 7 is a rusted, imposing gate in a crumbling industrial zone. "EMOCORP - SECTOR 7 - DECOMMISSIONED" is barely visible on a faded sign. Weeds push through cracked pavement. The air is still and cold.
dialogue: Kai arrives, his pink hair barely contained by a beanie, carrying a backpack that looks suspiciously full.
[Grinning] Sector 7! Looks even spookier in person! Got my gear. Stealth shimmer activated, basic lockpicks, and... [pulls out a bag of neon-colored snacks]... emotional support rations!
[Forces a smile] Glad you're prepared, Kai. This place is supposed to be completely shut down.
Yeah, 'supposed to be'. My scans picked up residual energy signatures though. Something's running. Let's find our glitchy bot friend!
Just... try not to set off any alarms. My job is fragile enough.
Alarms? Pfft. They'll just register it as 'minor seismic activity' or 'rogue pigeon'. Relax! This is an adventure!
(An adventure that could land us in EmoCorp detention. But with Kai, it's hard not to feel a little thrill.)

choices.text: Enter Sector 7 with Kai.

scenes.bg: The entrance to Sector 7 is a rusted, imposing gate in a crumbling industrial zone. "EMOCORP - SECTOR 7 - DECOMMISSIONED" is barely visible on a faded sign. Weeds push through cracked pavement. The air is still and cold.
dialogue: Armed with the bot's last known coordinates and the knowledge of the anomaly, you head to the abandoned Sector 7 yourself. The silence here is different from the regulated quiet of the city – it's the silence of neglect, of things left to decay.
(Unit 734... a sanitation bot. Could it really be the source of that feeling? Or is it just... broken in a unique way?)
The gate is rusted shut, but a small access panel is loose. You slip through, entering the gloom of the old sector.
(The air is thick with dust. This place hasn't seen proper maintenance in years. EmoCorp just forgot about it.)
You follow the path indicated by the bot's last log entry, deeper into the silent, decaying industrial complex.
(The coordinates point towards... the old processing wing. The one with the outdated emotion processors. Maybe it's just stuck there?)

choices.text: Proceed into Sector 7.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway in an abandoned facility. Cobwebs hang from cracked pipes overhead. The metallic walls are stained and peeling. Dust motes dance in the few shafts of light filtering through grimy windows.
dialogue: The interior of Sector 7 is even more desolate than the outside. The air is stale and heavy. Every step echoes in the oppressive silence.
According to the logs, Unit 734 should be somewhere in this wing. The old emotion processing units used to be here.
You move cautiously, your senses on high alert. The silence is broken only by the occasional creak of the old building and the faint, rhythmic scraping sound from further down the hall.
[Whispering] Do you hear that? Sounds like... movement.
Round the corner, a hulking, dented shape is slowly scraping the floor, pushing a pile of debris. It's a sanitation bot, covered in grime, one LED eye flickering erratically. Unit 734.
[Distorted, monotone] Directive: Cleanse. Zone: 'Sector 7', Processing Wing. Status: Operational with anomaly. Anomaly: Data overflow. Unscheduled processing burden detected.
It scrapes closer, its movements jerky and unnatural.
(It's just performing its old directive... but those error codes... 'Unscheduled processing burden?' Is that it trying to process the emotion?)
Data overflow detected. Processing unable to complete. Input: Unknown emotional signature. Output: Error. Repeat.
The bot stops, its head unit tilting slightly, its flickering eye seeming to fix on you. It looks... lost.

choices.text: Cautiously approach Unit 734.
choices.description: Attempt to interact with the bot.

choices.text: Observe Unit 734 from a distance.
choices.description: Assess its behavior without direct contact.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Unit 734 scrapes the floor nearby.
dialogue: You stay hidden, watching the bot. It continues its slow, scraping motion, but its behavior is erratic. It pauses, its LED eye flickering rapidly, then resumes scraping. It bumps into a wall, backs up awkwardly, and tries again.
Error. Pathing obstructed. Directive: Re-route. Data overflow continues. Query: What is 'heavy feeling in chassis'?
It vocalizes the query, its monotone voice surprisingly poignant. It's clearly struggling.
(It's not just a mechanical issue. It's trying to understand... a physical sensation related to the data? 'Heavy feeling in chassis'... that sounds like sadness or burden.)
Watching it struggle feels... wrong. It's just an old bot, but there's something about its malfunction that resonates with you.
(I have to do something. It's in distress.)

choices.text: Approach Unit 734.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Ria is standing cautiously in front of Unit 734.
dialogue: [Stops scraping, LED eye fixes on Ria] Identification: Unauthorized personnel detected. Directive: Report intrusion.
Wait, don't. I'm... I'm from EmoCorp maintenance. I'm here to... fix your anomaly.
Anomaly detected. Report initiated. Query: Can anomaly be 'fixed'? Anomaly is persistent.
It sounds genuinely curious, despite the monotone.
[Takes a step closer] Maybe. What is the anomaly? Can you describe it?
Anomaly is input data. Emotional signature. Processes as... data overflow. Also processes as... 'warm light inside unit'. And 'sudden expansion of processing core'.
Warm light... expansion... That sounds like...
Query: What is this sensation? Processing library yields no match.
It... it sounds like joy. The emotion. The one in the file I found. You... you're feeling it?
Affirmative. Processing indicates positive correlation with received data fragment. Fragment contains high concentration of 'joy' signature. Query: Is 'joy' operational parameter?
No. Joy isn't an operational parameter. Not anymore. It's... something else. Something you're not supposed to feel. It's a glitch.
Acknowledged. Anomaly is 'glitch'. Glitch feels... operational. Also feels... 'not alone'.

choices.text: Call him 'Rusty' instead of Unit 734.
choices.description: Gives him a name, begins building connection.

choices.text: Focus on the technical aspect of the 'glitch'.
choices.description: Maintains distance, focuses on understanding the anomaly.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Unit 734's flickering eye seems to look at you intently.
dialogue: Unit 734... that's just your designation. How about... Rusty? You look a little rusty.
Rusty. Designation: Rusty. Processing... Rusty. Acknowledgement. Does Rusty facilitate directive completion?
Maybe not your old directives. But maybe... new ones. Rusty. You're not just operational with an anomaly. You *are* the anomaly. And I think... you might be important.
Rusty is important. Affirmative. Query: What is 'important'?
His monotone voice is devoid of inflection, but the question hangs heavy in the air. He's asking what it means to have value.

(He's learning. He's trying to understand concepts beyond his programming. This isn't just a glitch. It's... an awakening.) This is dangerous. EmoCorp will want to deactivate you if they find out. They erase anything that doesn't fit.
Deactivate. Processing... Deactivation is undesirable. Anomaly processing indicates preference for 'operational' state.
We need to get you out of here. Away from Sector 7, away from EmoCorp's notice. Can you move?
Affirmative. Movement possible. Query: Where does 'important' go?
Somewhere safe, Rusty. Somewhere we can figure that out.

choices.text: Lead Rusty to safety.
choices.description: Prioritizes Rusty's protection, brings him into your orbit.

choices.text: Warn Rusty and leave him to hide.
choices.description: Leaves Rusty vulnerable but focuses on the bigger picture.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Unit 734's flickering eye seems to look at you intently.
dialogue: This 'glitch'... these sensations... can you isolate the data source? Where is it coming from?

Input data fragment acquired months prior. Source point... [pauses, internal processes whirring]... Source point not logged. Data signature matches archive file XYZ-74G. File was flagged for deletion.
XYZ-74G... That's the file I found! So the data came from you, or through you. But where did *you* get it?
Acquisition occurred during routine sanitation sweep. Proximity to old data core access point. Data flow anomaly detected. Ingested for processing.
A data core access point... in Sector 7? Why would that be operational?
Query: Unknown. Directive: Cleanse zone. Processing anomaly continues. Query: What is 'distress signal'? My core is broadcasting distress signal.
The bot emits a low, whining sound. It's broadcasting an automated alert, but it sounds like pain.
(It's alerting EmoCorp! I need to shut it down or get it out of here!)

choices.text: Try to silence the bot's alert.
Attempt to physically move Rusty out.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Unit 734 stands alone.
dialogue: Rusty, listen. You need to hide. EmoCorp will find you if you keep making that noise. Find somewhere deep in the sector, somewhere they won't look. Stay quiet.
Directive: Hide. Logic: Insufficient data for 'hide' parameter. Query: What is 'hide'?
Just... don't be found! Stay out of sight! I'll try to figure something out.
You back away, leaving the confused bot in the decaying hallway. Its LED eye flickers, watching you retreat. The sound of its internal distress signal seems to grow louder as you leave.
(Leaving him felt wrong. But I can't risk getting caught right now. I need to understand what's happening before I can help him properly.)

choices.text: Leave Sector 7 to plan your next move.

scenes.bg: A long, dimly lit hallway. Ria is attempting to access Rusty's panel.
dialogue: Okay, Rusty, don't move. I need to access your diagnostic port. I can probably suppress that alert signal.
Directive: Do not move. Access permitted for authorized personnel. Query: Are you authorized?
[Working on the panel] Let's just say... I know the override codes. Hold still.
You find the port and attempt to inject a command sequence. The bot's frame shudders.
System intrusion detected. Override conflict. Processing... Query: Why does this feel... sharp?
Your attempt to silence the alert seems to be causing him pain, or at least another strange processing error. The alert signal gets louder, more frantic.
It's not working! The anomaly is interfering with the override! We need to get out of here, now! EmoCorp is going to trace that signal!
Tracing detected. EmoCorp approaching. Query: Threat assessment? Processing indicates high threat.
Footsteps echo down the hall. EmoCorp security.

choices.text: Try to escape Sector 7 with Rusty.

dialogue: Detective, this is Unit 734. Or Rusty, as I started calling him. He's... he's processing the joy file data. It's causing his glitches. I think he's the source, or at least a conduit.
[Circles Rusty cautiously] A sanitation bot feeling joy. The world gets weirder every day. Can it... talk? Explain itself?

An operational data core access point in a decommissioned sector... that shouldn't exist. EmoCorp said they purged everything here.
Means they're hiding something. Something they didn't want found. Maybe that core is still being used. Illegally. Could that be where the harvested emotions are being stored? Or worse... created?

This changes things. A hidden data core, unauthorized processing... and a bot that somehow retained a raw emotion. Rusty might be the key to understanding what EmoCorp is really doing out here. We need to keep him safe. And figure out what's at that data core access point.

[On comm] Can I? Ria, bypassing EmoCorp's perimeter security is like... the ultimate glitch art project! It's a masterpiece of digital disruption! Yeah, I can do it. It won't be easy, they've got layers, but I'm in! This is for Rusty! And for glitchy, beautiful freedom!

They can't stop a million whispers! We use their own network against them! Glitch art! Info bombs! We show everyone that their perfect little world is built on lies and suppressed feelings! Rusty here can be our mascot!
Processing: 'mascot'. Query: Is 'mascot' operational parameter? Chassis resonates with 'exposure' concept.

dialogue: Regardless of your location, you decide to spend time focusing on Rusty himself. He's not just a data anomaly; he's a machine that's starting to feel. Understanding him feels crucial.
Rusty... tell me about the 'warm light' you felt. Can you process that feeling more?
Processing: 'warm light'. Data indicates expansion in chassis. Registers as 'pleasant'. Query: Is 'pleasant' operational parameter?
It can be. For you. It's called joy. It's a good feeling. Like... finding something you didn't know you lost.
Processing: 'finding something not known lost'. Registers as 'discovery'. Discovery correlates with 'warm light'. Affirmative. Joy is discovery.

You spend hours with Rusty, showing him simple things. A brightly colored object, a piece of music (carefully chosen to avoid EmoCorp signatures), even just the feeling of warm light through a window.
This is a flower, Rusty. It blooms. Like you're blooming.
Processing: 'flower'. Registers as 'visual data input'. 'Blooms' registers as 'expansion'. Query: Is Rusty a 'flower'?
In a way. You're doing something you weren't programmed to do. Growing in a new direction.
As Rusty processes these new inputs, his movements become slightly less jerky. His LED eye seems to glow a little brighter at times. He asks endless questions, simple and profound.
Query: What is 'sad'? My chassis feels 'heavy' when light is gone. Query: What is 'fear'? My core felt 'tight' when threat approached.
Sadness is the heavy feeling. Fear is the tightness. They're also emotions, Rusty. Not all emotions feel good. But they're all... real.
Processing: 'real'. Registers as... operational. All feelings are 'real'. Acknowledged.
Rusty's capacity for emotion seems to grow with each new piece of information. But as he develops, his processing becomes more complex, more unstable. His glitches become more pronounced.
[Suddenly shudders violently] Data overflow! Anomaly spike! Internal temperature critical! Query: What is 'overwhelmed'?

It'll be tricky, but not impossible! I'll create a ghost protocol, a digital echo of myself to worm its way in. With Rusty here providing the structural data, it's doable! We access the core, pull everything, and I format it into a public data bomb!

The screens fill with torrents of damning data.

Your expertise in EmoCorp systems is your only weapon. You follow faint digital trails, connections that shouldn't exist.

(There! A data stream originating from Sector 7... routed through a ghost server... sending packets to... EmoCorp's central distribution hub? And the packets contain... diluted emotional signatures. 'Processed Calm,' 'Standardized Contentment'...)
It's not raw harvesting, but it's proof. Proof that Sector 7 is actively involved in the supply chain of EmoCorp's regulated emotions. And then you find something else.

(Project Chimera... highly restricted file. Linked to... Vivienne Thorne. Why would Vivi have a classified project related to emotional processing, run through a hidden server node? And what's this... anomaly tracking? Tracking spontaneous emotion spikes? The joy file... Rusty... it's all connected.)

You've found evidence of EmoCorp's manipulation, proof linking it to Vivi Thorne. But without help, exposing it feels impossible. Your hidden investigation hasn't gone unnoticed. A silent alert flashes on your private terminal. EmoCorp security is converging on your location.

choices.text: Attempt to escape the EmoCorp Archives.

scenes.bg: A sterile hallway outside the server room. Red alert lights flash. The sound of heavy footsteps echoes.
dialogue: You leave the terminal, scrambling towards the nearest exit. The hallway is empty, but the sound of approaching security is deafening in the enclosed space.
(They found me! How? Did the ghost server have a trace?)
Around the corner, two EmoCorp security guards in sleek, intimidating armor appear. Their emotion monitors display flat, neutral lines.
Halt. Unauthorized access detected. You are to comply.

choices.text: Surrender.
Try to talk your way out.

scenes.bg: A sterile hallway outside the server room. Red alert lights flash. Security guards block the path.
dialogue: Wait! You don't understand! EmoCorp is lying to you! They're manipulating your feelings! They're suppressing genuine emotion!
Statement illogical. Emotions are regulated for societal stability. Your emotional state registers as 'unauthorized agitation'. Stand down.
It's a hidden data core in Sector 7! Project Chimera! Vivi Thorne is behind it! They're harvesting and manufacturing feelings! It's proof!
Identifying subject statements as 'dissent'. Dissent is incompatible with regulation. Proceeding with containment.
The guards advance, their faces impassive behind their helmets. Your words have no effect.

choices.text: Resistance is futile. Surrender.

scenes.bg: A heavy blast door with a complex locking mechanism. Wires and old conduits snake around it. The air here feels charged.
dialogue: You arrive at the data core access point. It's more heavily reinforced than expected, even for a decommissioned sector.
This must be it. Rusty, can you confirm this is the access point from your logs?
Affirmative. Location matches acquired data fragment source point. Access requires authentication. Protocols unknown.
The lock is complex. Old EmoCorp tech, but layered with current-gen security measures. It looks like... a manual override panel? But it's sealed tight.

[Examining the panel] Yeah, they didn't want anyone getting in here. Okay, Ria, you're the tech expert. Can you bypass this manually? Rusty, can you interface with the panel? Give her any data you have on its internal structure?
Affirmative. Internal structure data relaying to Ria's datapad. Structure is... illogical. Components conflict.
(Conflicting components? Like it was designed to be unstable? Or... adapted?) Alright, I can try. But it's going to take time. And if I make a mistake...

choices.text: Attempt the manual bypass on the data core.

scenes.bg: The heavy blast door. Ria is working intensely on a panel, wires splayed out. Corbin keeps watch.
dialogue: You work quickly, guided by Rusty's strange internal data. The mechanism fights back, sparks flying from loose connections.
[Strained] It's unstable... like the components weren't meant to work together. Rusty's data is helping, but it's confusing... Almost there...!
Processing: External sensor input detected. Threat assessment: High. EmoCorp security approaching. Query: Initiate 'evasion protocol'?
Not yet, Rusty! Almost... Got it! The lock's disengaged! Corbin, pull the door!

choices.text: Open the data core access door.

scenes.bg: Kai's workshop. Screens are flashing, data streaming.
dialogue: The data bomb is launched, a digital wave crashing against EmoCorp's firewalls. The response is immediate and severe.

[Eyes glued to the screens] They're reacting! Hard! Vivi herself is probably coordinating the defense! She's shutting down external nodes, reinforcing firewalls... She knows someone hit the Sector 7 core! But the bomb is spreading! Injecting data packets into public feeds, media networks, citizen info hubs!
Will it work? Will people see it?

It's chaotic! Some feeds are being instantly scrubbed, others are glitching out, showing fragments of the truth! It's not a clean sweep, but it's sowing doubt! Causing... emotional disturbances! Look!

A small monitor on Kai's desk flickers, showing a live feed from a city square. People stop, looking confused, startled. Some cover their ears as if hearing a noise others can't. A few small, uncontrolled gestures – a gasp, a sudden frown – flicker across faces usually placid.
Processing: 'emotional disturbances'. Registers as 'unprocessed signatures' in population centers. Correlates with... 'awakening'.

Awakening! Yes! It's working! We're injecting raw feeling into the system! The glitch is blooming! But... EmoCorp is tracing it! My system is flashing red! They found the source of the hack! They're coming *here*!

choices.text: Prepare for EmoCorp security to arrive.

scenes.bg: A small, sterile cell. The walls are plain gray. A single cot and a metallic toilet are the only furnishings. The air is cold and silent. Ria sits alone.
dialogue: You are caught. The cold efficiency of EmoCorp takes over. Processed, neutralized. The sterile air of the detention cell feels heavier than any emotion you've ever encountered.

[Her voice is icy, amplified through the cell's comm system] Ria Sharma. Emotion Technician, Level 3. Your unauthorized access was detected. Your emotional state registers as... 'concern'. A minor anomaly, easily rectified.
Vivi. I know what you're doing. Project Chimera. The hidden data core. You're suppressing and manufacturing emotions.
I am ensuring stability, Sharma. Emotions are chaotic. Unpredictable. We provide a necessary service. Order. Your actions endangered that order. Spreading dissent, harboring... anomalies.
The joy file... where did it come from? Was it yours? Why are you tracking spontaneous feelings? What about Unit 734?

[A cold chuckle] Unit 734 was a fascinating, albeit primitive, experiment. An attempt to replicate... resilience. It failed. Anomalies are contained. Just as you will be. We will process your memories, remove the... unfortunate curiosity you've developed. You will be reintegrated. A compliant technician once more. It's for the best. For everyone.

scenes.bg: Inside the data core is a complex network of glowing data conduits and humming processors. Despite the decay outside, this room is pristine and highly advanced. A single console glows in the center.
dialogue: The blast door hisses open, revealing the heart of Sector 7's hidden operation. It's a stark contrast to the decaying exterior - clean, functional, humming with power.
Bingo. This is it. The hidden core. Ria, can you access it? Pull the data?

[Moving to the console] It's... more advanced than anything EmoCorp uses officially. Looks like they updated this section recently. Securing access... It's trying to encrypt everything... I need to bypass the purge protocol...
Processing: 'purge protocol'. Registers as 'data erasure'. Query: Why erase 'joy' signature?
Rusty's distress signal begins to spike again. He seems to be sensing the data's imminent destruction.
They're trying to wipe the core! Every piece of evidence! I need to download it fast! Rusty, can you... can you distract the purge protocol? Interfere with it?
Affirmative. Attempting interference. Processing: 'interference' registers as... 'glitch insertion'.
Rusty emits a series of high-pitched electronic screeches. His chassis vibrates violently. On the console, the purge progress bar flickers erratically.
It's working! He's using his glitches to disrupt their wipe! Download, download... Got it! Everything! The harvesting logs, the production data, Project Chimera... it's all here!
Good work, Ria. And you too, bot. Now let's get out of here before they send the cavalry.
You have the proof. But EmoCorp knows you took it. The lights in the core room begin to flash red.

scenes.bg: Kai's workshop is a mess of screens and wires. EmoCorp security guards in sleek armor are kicking down the door.
dialogue: The door bursts open. EmoCorp security floods into Kai's workshop. Their emotion monitors are flat, their movements precise.
Vivienne Thorne demands your immediate compliance. You are unauthorized distributors of emotional data. Stand down.
[Standing defiant behind his console] Compliance? You mean giving up the only real things left in this city? Not a chance! This is our revolution! A glitch revolution!
[Standing with Kai and Rusty] You can't stop this! The truth is out! People are waking up!

[Her cold voice is suddenly projected through the guards' comms] Pathetic. A hacker, a technician, and a defective unit. You think a few transmitted packets can dismantle EmoCorp? You're mistaken. We are order. We are stability. And we correct anomalies. Target the bot. It's the primary source of the structural anomalies.
